choices.C: Create a hold on the user's mailbox in Google Vault
choices.D: Reset the user's password, and share the new password with the litigation team.
choices.B: Create a matter using Google Vault, and share the matter with the litigation team members.
choices.E: Copy the user's data to a secondary account.
choices.A: Move the user to their own Organization Unit, and set a custom retention policy

questions.question_text:
You are supporting an investigation that is being conducted by your litigation team. The current default retention policy for mail is 180 days, and there are no custom mail retention policies in place. The litigation team has identified a user who is central to the investigation, and they want to investigate the mail data related to this user without the user's awareness.
What two actions should you take? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
B and C also can
https://support.google.com/vault/answer/2473591

Use holds to preserve data indefinitely to meet legal or preservation obligations.
A and B

Selected Answer: BC
correct answer is B & C

Selected Answer: BC
You have to create a new matter in Google Vault with a hold on the user's mailbox in Google Vault to overide the default preservation rule.
B+C is correct
Hello, what would be the correct answers?

A and B.

I think that C can not be possible because the retention rule always apply to UO.
D can not be possible because the user would know. So B and C.
B and C is correct
B and C is correct answer here.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct. Downloading the user information from AC > Users will show the user status for all users and their OU.

C is incorrect since it will show in the report only the changes of user status in the last 6 months so the data might be incomplete.

Selected Answer: D
D : you can get as a Google Sheet the list of all users including OUs and User state (active or suspended), and all other information like Storage used, last sign in, ....But should be "All columns" and not "Currently selected columns".
C is correct
D is the correct answer.

comments.content: Sorry, error ... you have to go into user reports to see the status of each user and then export the content to a google sheet, so the right answer is C --->https://support.google.com/cloudidentity/answer/4580176?hl=en#zippy=%2Cgeneral

questions.question_text:
Your Accounts Payable department is auditing software license contracts companywide and has asked you to provide a report that shows the number of active and suspended users by organization unit, which has been set up to match the Regions and Departments within your company. You need to produce a Google
Sheet that shows a count of all active user accounts and suspended user accounts by Org unit.
What should you do?

choices.A: From the Admin Console Billing Menu, turn off auto-assign, and then click into Assigned Users and export the data to Sheets.
choices.C: From the G Suite Reports Menu, run and download the Accounts Aggregate report, and export the data to Google Sheets.
choices.D: From the Admin Console Users Menu, download a list of all user info columns and currently selected columns.
choices.B: From the Admin Console Users Menu, download a list of all Users to Google Sheets, and join that with a list of ORGIDs pulled from the Reports API.

questions.question_text:
Your organization is part of a highly regulated industry with a very high turnover. In order to recycle licenses for new employees and comply with data retention regulations, it has been determined that certain G Suite data should be stored in a separate backup environment.
How should you store data for this situation?

choices.D: Train users to use Google Takeout and store their archives locally.
choices.B: Write a script and use G Suite APIs to access and download user data.
choices.C: Use a third-party tool to configure secure backup of G Suite data.
choices.A: Use routing rules to dual-deliver mail to an on-premises SMTP server and G Suite.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
correct answer is C

Best option should be to use Archived user licence but not listed.
A will only preserve email.
B and C can preserve email and drive.
C is correct

comments.content: But honestly I realised now that it depends what is meant by certain G suite data..... My answer would be valid only if they meant mails only
It's wrong because the dual-delivery doesn't do a copy of the previous data.

discussion.content: It's A because this is the most straightforward solution and it doesn't rely on third-party-tools, which would not be considered as best practice. See details about dual-delivery here if you're unaware of that: https://support.google.com/a/answer/9228551?hl=en
C for me is correct answer, You can use solution like Spinbackup.

questions.question_text:
You recently started an engagement with an organization that is also using G Suite. The engagement will involve highly sensitive data, and the data needs to be protected from being shared with unauthorized parties both internally and externally. You need to ensure that this data is properly secured.
Which configuration should you implement?

choices.C: Configure the Drive DLP rules to prevent the sharing of PII and PHI outside of your domain.
choices.A: Turn on external sharing with whitelisted domains, and add the external organization to the whitelist.
choices.D: Create a Team Drive for this engagement, and limit the memberships and sharing settings.
choices.B: Provision accounts within your domain for the external users, and turn off external sharing for that Org.

discussion.content: Option A: Without turning on External sharing, how we can share the file with team drive.

Selected Answer: D
Option A is a partial solution, it does not prevent internal sharing.

Selected Answer: D
D will centralize information in a secured area where only approved, internal and external users can collaborate.

comments.content: Yeah but if you have Frontline, G Suite basic or Workspace Business Starter, they won't be able to only view the shared drive content within their organization. So it will be a limited access.

discussion.content: D is correct
Option A is a partial solution, it does not prevent internal sharing. Option D is the correct option
go for D

I will also go with Option D

https://support.google.com/a/users/answer/9310352#1.1
A allows to share with the whitelisting domain but not protect for been sharing with others, D allows to collaborate and limits the sharing

correct answer letter D
https://support.google.com/a/users/answer/9310352#1.1

D 
Based from the question, the data needs to be protected from being shared with unauthorized parties both internally and externally.

questions.question_text:
You have configured your G Suite account on the scheduled release track to provide additional time to prepare for new product releases and determine how they will impact your users. There are some new features on the latest roadmap that your director needs you to test as soon as they become generally available without changing the release track for the entire organization.
What should you do?

choices.B: Create a new Google Group with test users and enable the rapid release track.
choices.D: Ask Google for a demo account with beta access to the new features.
choices.A: Create a new OU and tum on the rapid release track just for this OU.
choices.C: Establish a separate Dev environment, and set it to rapid release.

discussion.content: C is best possible option, this is only way you can achieve this.

comments.content: This setting cannot be applied at OU level. So C is correct.

Agree on this, because question also mentions "as soon as it is generally available". So we do not need beta features but rather rapid release track on Demo environment. If question would be written differently i would choose D then, but not in this case.

discussion.content: Vote for C. Admin console cannot set rapid/schedule release by OU

comments.content: This seems like the correct option, but find it hard to believe that Google does not provide this setting at a OU level.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Answer is "C". There is no OU setting.

comments.content: Hey mate . I want to know Google changed this certificate into Google workspace so can I take this exam as preparation into Google workspace exam
Collaboration Engineer has been renamed to Workspace Admin, it is the same exam.

discussion.content:
Correct answer is (C):

Tip for large organizations: Select the Scheduled Release track for your production account. Then set up Rapid Release on a test account to try new features before they’re available to your users.

https://support.google.com/a/answer/172177

Selected Answer: C
A dev account is the best way because you can't define this setting on a OU or group basis.
